source: Library of Congress, FSA/OWI Black-and-White Negatives
creditLine: Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, FSA/OWI Collection

photos.title: Rear of apartment house showing Milwaukee courthouse
photos.caption: The back of an apartment building near the new Milwaukee courthouse — conditions HOLC appraisers would evaluate two years later.

photos.title: Housing under Wisconsin Avenue viaduct
photos.caption: Homes tucked beneath the Wisconsin Avenue viaduct. Living in the shadow of infrastructure, literally.

photos.title: Slums. Milwaukee, Wisconsin
photos.caption: Housing in what the government called 'slums' — neighborhoods that would be graded D (Hazardous) by HOLC.

photos.title: Closeup of rear of houses, 900 block West Clyburn Street
photos.caption: Rear view of houses on West Clyburn Street's 900 block. Back-of-house conditions factored heavily into HOLC grading.

photos.title: Residential houses crowded in industrial district
photos.caption: Residential housing pressed against Milwaukee's industrial zone — proximity to factories lowered HOLC grades.

photos.title: Milwaukee freight yards and industrial plants
photos.caption: Milwaukee's freight yards overshadowed by a residential district. Industrial employment drew workers, but living nearby meant lower property values.

photos.title: House on alley between 7th and 8th Streets
photos.caption: A house on the alley between 7th and 8th and Milbourn and State Streets. HOLC appraisers would walk these blocks and decide their future.

photos.title: Rear of apartments at 8th and Wisconsin
photos.caption: Apartment buildings at 8th and Wisconsin Avenue, with the Milwaukee Public Library in background. The heart of what would become a C-graded zone.

photos.title: House at 437 North Jackson Street
photos.caption: 437 North Jackson Street. Specific addresses documented by the FSA — many of these buildings are now gone.

photos.title: Alley and houses at 1012 West Somers Street
photos.caption: Looking down the alley at 1012 West Somers Street. Alleys were gathering places and sometimes the only outdoor space.

photos.title: View from living quarters at 730 West Winnebago Street
photos.caption: The view from inside a home at 730 West Winnebago Street, looking toward the alley. Daily life in a neighborhood the government would soon label 'Hazardous.'

photos.title: Rear of houses, 900 block West Clybourn Street
photos.caption: Rear of a group of houses on West Clybourn Street. What front facades hid, back alleys revealed.

photos.title: 1316 West Walnut Street blight
photos.caption: 1316 West Walnut Street. The word 'blight' in the caption — the same language HOLC appraisers would use to justify redlining.

photos.title: Group of houses at 9th and Galena Street
photos.caption: Houses at 9th and Galena Street. Whether this block was graded A or D would determine mortgage access for decades.

photos.title: Unemployed men salvaging coke from industrial cinder pile
photos.caption: Unemployed men salvaging coke from an industrial cinder pile at the Milwaukee Railroad shops. HOLC appraisers noted the 'class' of residents as part of their assessments.

photos.title: Group of houses, 600 block East Detroit Street
photos.caption: A group of houses on East Detroit Street. Two years later, an appraiser would assign a single letter grade to determine this block's financial future.

photos.title: Close housing adjoining junk
photos.caption: Houses pressed up against a junk yard. Proximity to 'detrimental influences' was one of the factors HOLC used to downgrade neighborhoods.

photos.title: Housing alongside Chicago and Milwaukee Railroad
photos.caption: Houses alongside the Chicago and Milwaukee Railroad. Railroads and industry drove HOLC grades down in adjacent neighborhoods.

photos.title: 1535 North 10th Street, house next to junk yard
photos.caption: 1535 North 10th Street, a house next to a junk yard. Addresses documented by the FSA — many of these buildings are now gone.

photos.title: Exterior of house at 912 North 8th Street
photos.caption: 912 North 8th Street. The lines drawn on maps in 1938 would shape opportunities on this block for generations.
